name: Shanghai
fun_fact: Fun fact: Xiaolongbao was invented in 1871 in a small village called Nanxiang (now part of Shanghai), and the original restaurant still operates in Yuyuan Gardenâ€”where you can watch soup dumplings being hand-folded with exactly 18 pleats, a technique that hasn't changed in 150 years.

hero_dishes.name: Xiaolongbao at Lai Lai
hero_dishes.description: Delicate soup dumplings with paper-thin wrappers holding a burst of hot, savory broth and pork fillingâ€”sucking out the soup is an art form
hero_dishes.origin_story: Lai Lai's Tianjin Lu location earned a Michelin Guide Bib Gourmand in 2024. Their xiaolongbao have impossibly thin wrappers that somehow hold a river of soup. The technique requires years of training to achieve 18 perfect pleats
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Lai Lai (Tianjin Luâ€”Michelin Bib Gourmand 2024), Linlongfang Xiaolongbao (off-shoot of Jia Jia Tangbao), Nanxiang in Yuyuan Garden (the 150-year-old original)

hero_dishes.name: Shengjianbao at Da Hu Chun
hero_dishes.description: Pan-fried pork buns with crispy golden bottoms and fluffy tops, filled with soup and meatâ€”the street food cousin of xiaolongbao
hero_dishes.origin_story: Shengjianbao was created over 100 years ago as dim sum in Shanghai tea houses. Da Hu Chun perfected the technique: crispy bottom, soft top, soup inside. It's served at breakfast but eaten all day
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Da Hu Chun (best in Shanghai), Yang's Fried Dumplings (97 Huang He Roadâ€”reliable chain locals trust)

hero_dishes.name: Hairy Crab (seasonal)
hero_dishes.description: Shanghai's most prized seasonal delicacyâ€”small freshwater crabs with sweet, creamy roe, steamed and eaten with vinegar and ginger
hero_dishes.origin_story: Hairy crabs from Yangcheng Lake arrive in Shanghai every autumn, causing a citywide frenzy. The roe is considered liquid gold. Locals spend hundreds on authentic crabs, and counterfeits are a real problem
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Seasonal (September-November) at high-end Shanghainese restaurants and specialty crab shops

hero_dishes.name: Scallion Oil Noodles
hero_dishes.description: Simple wheat noodles tossed in fragrant scallion oil with soy sauceâ€”minimalist but addictively savory
hero_dishes.origin_story: This humble dish shows Shanghai's knack for making magic from almost nothing. The scallion oil is fried slowly until dark and intensely aromatic. It's comfort food that costs pennies
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Local noodle shops throughout Shanghai, especially in old neighborhoods

signature_drinks.name: Soy Milk (Doujiang)
signature_drinks.description: Hot, unsweetened soy milk served with youtiao (fried dough sticks) for dippingâ€”the classic Shanghai breakfast
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Fresh-made at breakfast shops, served piping hot in bowls. Locals tear youtiao into pieces and dunk them in soy milk. It's the breakfast of choice before work

signature_drinks.name: Osmanthus Wine
signature_drinks.description: Sweet, floral wine infused with osmanthus flowersâ€”delicate and fragrant
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served slightly chilled in small cups at banquets and special occasions. The osmanthus flower blooms in fall, making it seasonal. It's elegant and uniquely Shanghainese

food_culture_notes: Xiaolongbao etiquette: bite a tiny hole, suck out the soup, then eat the dumplingâ€”using chopsticks only
Authentic xiaolongbao should have exactly 18 pleats, though most diners can't count them before devouring
Hairy crab season (autumn) is serious businessâ€”restaurants require reservations months in advance
Shengjianbao is breakfast food, but Yang's Fried Dumplings made it an all-day affair

landmarks: Yu Garden and classical Chinese gardens
atmosphere: modern skyscrapers meeting old longtang neighborhoods
